metadata.title: Voynich Visual Coding - Complete Dataset
metadata.description: Visual feature coding plus plant identification guesses

pdf_notes.f1r_page_3: Text-only page, possibly preface - no plant illustration
pdf_notes.bleed_through: Many pages show bleed-through from opposite side (verso). Check actual illustration on correct side.

f38r.heading: tolor

identification.reasoning: Single large lobed leaf with white stem. White comma-shaped markings distinctive. Arum has single large leaves and was common in medieval herbals.
identification.medieval_use: Medicinal (though toxic)

f38r.notes: Single large lobed leaf with white comma-shaped markings, white/cream stem

f9v.heading: fochor

identification.reasoning: Opposite oval leaves, branching woody stem, small flowers at leaf axils. Myrtle extremely common in medieval Mediterranean.
identification.medieval_use: Perfume, medicine, sacred plant, symbol of love

f9v.notes: Branching shrub with opposite oval leaves, small reddish buds

f56r.heading: otchal

identification.reasoning: Blue radial flowers with white rays, thin stem, serrated basal leaves. Chicory has iconic blue flowers and was widely used in medieval medicine.
identification.medieval_use: Digestive aid, liver tonic, eaten as vegetable

f56r.notes: Striking blue radial flowers with white centers, thin tan stem, green serrated basal leaves

f3v.heading: koaiin

identification.reasoning: Single large round/kidney-shaped leaf on thin curved stem. Asarabacca was important medieval medicine with distinctive round leaves.
identification.medieval_use: Emetic, purgative, sneezing powder

f3v.notes: Single large round/kidney-shaped leaf, thin curved green stem, no root or flower shown

f42r.heading: sho

identification.reasoning: Arrow-shaped leaf with pointed basal lobes, long straight stem, bulbous node at leaf-stem junction. Orange 3-petaled structure matches Sagittaria's 3-petaled flowers. Leaf and flower shown separately but are same plant.
identification.medieval_use: Edible tubers, wetland plant, food source

f42r.notes: Arrow-shaped green leaf with basal points, long thin stem, branching roots. Orange 3-petaled flower shown separately. Strong match to Sagittaria latifolia.

f10v.heading: paiin

identification.reasoning: Blue flowers terminal on stems, feathery/spiny bracts on upper stems, different leaf shapes at base vs top (oval below, compound above). Classic Nigella characteristics.
identification.medieval_use: Seeds as spice (black cumin), medicine, perfume

f10v.notes: Blue flowers at stem tips, spiny/feathery leaves on upper branches, oval/pointy leaves at base. Strong Nigella match.

f11v.heading: poldchody

identification.reasoning: Blue/purple drooping bell-shaped flowers, large oval leaves, thick knotty root. Flower shape matches comfrey well. Note: Real comfrey has more erect/spiny leaves; drawing shows droopy leaves (artistic license or wilted).
identification.medieval_use: Major wound healer, bone-knitting (knitbone), poultices

f11v.notes: Two curved stems with drooping blue bell flowers, large wavy oval leaves, thick root. Flowers match comfrey; leaves depicted droopier than real plant.

f51v.heading: poshody

identification.reasoning: Tall straight stem with small blue dots/flowers at top, large twisted wavy leaves wrapped around stem. Woad was major medieval blue dye plant. Hard to identify definitively.
identification.medieval_use: Primary source of blue dye in medieval Europe

f51v.notes: Tall stem, small blue flower/berry clusters at top, large twisted wavy green leaves, branching roots. Difficult to identify - possibly Woad.

f23v.heading: podairol

identification.reasoning: Blue 5-pointed star-shaped flowers are classic borage. Rounded/scalloped leaves with fuzzy texture depicted. Red-tinged branching root. Flower variations match real borage.
identification.medieval_use: Borage for courage - mood enhancer, cooling herb, added to wine

f23v.notes: Blue star-shaped flowers, rounded scalloped leaves with fuzzy appearance, red branching root. Strong borage match.

f5v.heading: kocheor

identification.reasoning: Twisted intertwined root (like mandrake), spiny/needle leaves, single flower with spiny bract projection. Curved wavy leaves also present. Sea Holly has all these features and twisted roots were candied as eryngo.
identification.medieval_use: Candied roots (eryngo) as aphrodisiac, medicinal

f5v.notes: Distinctive twisted/intertwined root, spiny radiating leaves, single flower with spiny projection, curved leaves on left side. Multiple elements may show different parts of same plant.

f45v.heading: korary

identification.reasoning: Very distinctive chain of tuberous/nodular root swellings like string of beads wrapping around page. Small opposite leaves, blue flowers at branch tips. Dropwort has characteristic bead-like root tubers.
identification.medieval_use: Medicinal, roots edible

f45v.notes: Distinctive beaded/nodular root chain wrapping around page, branching stem with small opposite leaves, blue terminal flowers.

f29v.heading: kooiin

identification.reasoning: Single purple flower at top, several aqua-colored bulbs/buds on separate stems, 2 large bushy/pointy divided leaf clusters at mid-stem, split knotty fibrous brown root. Pasque flower has purple flowers and feathery divided leaves.
identification.medieval_use: Medicinal - sedative, skin conditions

f29v.notes: Purple flower at top, aqua bulbs/buds on stems, 2 bushy/pointy leaf clusters, split knotty fibrous root. Colors: purple flower, aqua buds, green leaves, brown root.

f2r.heading: kydainy

identification.reasoning: Branching shrub with many oval leaves in two colors (green and tan/orange - possibly showing different leaf stages or autumn colors). Small round flower/fruit at top. Fibrous tangled root. Bay laurel was extremely important in medieval times.
identification.medieval_use: Culinary herb, crowns of victory, medicinal (digestive, respiratory)

f2r.notes: CORRECTION: Initial analysis was of bleed-through from verso side. Actual illustration shows branching plant with two-toned leaves (green + tan/orange), small round terminal flower/fruit, fibrous root.

f4v.heading: pchooiin

identification.reasoning: Blue cone/warped shape flower with white flat spot at top, serrated spiny green leaves, orange-red branching root. Flower shape unusual - not a typical globe or funnel. Best guess based on serrated leaves + blue flower.
identification.medieval_use: Snakebite remedy, medicinal

f4v.notes: Unusual blue flower - warped cone shape with white flat spot, not globe or funnel. Serrated/spiny green leaves along stem, orange-red branching root.

f5r.heading: kshody

identification.reasoning: Bushy branching herb with many small opposite leaves, small blue flowers at branch tips. Pink/red coloring on some sections unusual. Wavy elements on left may be separate plant parts.
identification.medieval_use: Major medicinal herb - purification, respiratory ailments, holy herb

f5r.notes: Bushy branching plant with small pointed leaves (green and pink/red sections), small blue terminal flowers. Wavy structures on left side. Two-toned foliage unusual.

f25r.heading: fcholdy

identification.reasoning: Very clean symmetrical drawing. Opposite pointed oval leaves, small red/brown clustered flowers at leaf nodes, branching root. Classic nettle appearance.
identification.medieval_use: Food, fiber for cloth, medicine (blood purifier, diuretic, rheumatism)

f25r.notes: Clean symmetrical plant with opposite oval leaves, small red dots at leaf axils, straight stem, branching root.

f11r.heading: tshol

identification.reasoning: Distinctive paired bulbous roots (two red/orange radish-shaped tubers splitting from base). Single drooping spiny blue flower. Drooping serrated leaves in green/brown/yellow. Paired tubers are classic orchid feature.
identification.medieval_use: Major aphrodisiac (satyrion), love potions, fertility

f11r.notes: Single spiny blue flower at top, drooping serrated green-brown leaves, distinctive PAIRED red bulbous roots (one on each side like two radishes). Classic orchid tuber structure.

f38v.heading: okchop

identification.reasoning: Diamond/triangular shaped leaves match Aspen/Poplar well. Multi-colored leaves suggest autumn coloring. Tree-like growth with branching roots. NOTE: Blue star flower at top does NOT match (Aspen has catkins) - may be shown separately or artistic addition.
identification.medieval_use: Bark for fever (contains salicin like aspirin), wood for various uses

f38v.notes: Tree-like plant with many diamond-shaped leaves in green/yellow/white (autumn colors?). Blue star flower at top doesn't match Aspen - possibly separate element. Branching whitish roots.

f36r.heading: pchafdan

identification.reasoning: Deeply lobed palmate (hand-shaped) green leaves, yellowish-cream flower clusters throughout. Bushy growth. Classic Lady's Mantle appearance.
identification.medieval_use: Women's herb - menstrual issues, wound healing, important in alchemy

f36r.notes: Bushy plant with many deeply lobed palmate leaves, yellowish/cream flower clusters, fibrous brown root.

f30v.heading: cthscthain

identification.reasoning: Compound leaves with paired leaflets in olive/brown color. Small round flower/seed clusters on branching terminal stems. Classic agrimony appearance.
identification.medieval_use: Wound healing, liver ailments, digestive issues, dye plant

f30v.notes: Compound leaves with paired leaflets, small round dots/flowers on branching upper stems. No root shown.

f22v.heading: pysaiinor

identification.reasoning: Very unusual plant. Flower at top, synchronized leaf/branch groups on stem, multi-point stem-root connection, spiny/thorny root with extensions having links or bulbs. Solomon's Seal has jointed rhizome but this is a stretch.
identification.medieval_use: Solomon's Seal: wound healing, bone setting, skin conditions

f22v.notes: BIZARRE PLANT: Flower at top, very synchronized branch/leaf groups, stem splits into multi-point connection to spiny root with linked bulbous extensions. May be fantastical or highly stylized.

f32v.heading: kcheodaiin

identification.reasoning: Blue bell-shaped hooded flowers clustered at top. Deeply lobed palmate (star-shaped) leaves. Classic monkshood/wolfsbane appearance with characteristic helmet-shaped flowers.
identification.medieval_use: HIGHLY TOXIC - used externally for pain relief, poison for arrows/wolves, witch's plant

f32v.notes: Blue bell/hood-shaped flowers at top, deeply lobed star/palmate leaves. Strong monkshood match. User confirmed.

f17r.heading: fshody

identification.reasoning: Blue tubular flowers clustered at top in spike arrangement, large smooth oval leaves alternately arranged, thick straight stem, fibrous orange-brown root. Classic borage family appearance.
identification.medieval_use: Alkanet root for red dye, medicinal uses for skin and wounds

f17r.notes: Clean simple drawing. Blue tubular flower cluster, large oval leaves, fibrous root.

f18r.heading: pdrairdy

identification.reasoning: Dark blue flower at top with pointed petals, pale bud below, oval leaves arranged along stem, branching yellowish root. Periwinkle and Gentian both fit the oval leaves + blue flower combination.
identification.medieval_use: Periwinkle: wound healing, memory, magical protection. Gentian: digestive bitter, fever remedy.

f18r.notes: Blue flower at top, pale bud below, oval leaves on stem, branching root. Could be Periwinkle or Gentian.

f9r.heading: tydlo

identification.reasoning: Single arrow-shaped leaf pointing upward, horizontal leaf below. Arrow/sagittate leaves are characteristic of bindweed family.
identification.medieval_use: Purgative, binding wounds (hence name), considered problematic weed

f9r.notes: Single arrow-shaped leaf pointing up, horizontal leaf below. User confirmed Bindweed match.

f20v.heading: faiis

identification.reasoning: Delicate branching plant with small lanceolate leaves and blue tubular flowers at branch tips. Classic hyssop appearance.
identification.medieval_use: Major medicinal and sacred herb - purification, respiratory ailments, digestive, holy herb in Bible

f20v.notes: Delicate branching herb, small leaves, blue tubular flowers at tips. No visible root.

f47v.heading: psheot

identification.reasoning: Vine-like climbing plant with lobed/serrated leaves arranged along curving stem. Small flower/fruit at top. Bryony is a climbing vine with angular lobed leaves.
identification.medieval_use: TOXIC - purgative, used cautiously for rheumatism, dropsy. Root resembles mandrake.

f47v.notes: Climbing vine with lobed leaves curving across page, small flower at top, fibrous root. User confirmed Bryony.

f24v.heading: tchodar

identification.reasoning: Large palmate/star-shaped leaves radiating from center, prominent fibrous root system. Classic mandrake appearance, though leaves slightly different from typical depictions.
identification.medieval_use: FAMOUS magical/medicinal plant - anesthetic, love potions, fertility, believed to scream when pulled

f24v.notes: Large palmate leaves, prominent root. Mandrake-like but leaves slightly off. No flower shown.

f49v.heading: r*

identification.reasoning: Small blue flower at top, unique circular rosette/plume of overlapping rounded leaves, straight stem leading to white bulb with tendrils. Leaf pattern is very distinctive and doesn't clearly match any known plant.
identification.medieval_use: Wild leek/ramps: culinary, medicinal for digestion and respiratory

f49v.notes: UNIQUE leaf pattern - overlapping rounded leaves in circular rosette arrangement. White bulb with tendrils, small blue flower. Hard to identify definitively.
